name: Paro
fun_fact: Fun fact: Paro Airport is considered one of the world's most dangerous airports - only 24 pilots in the entire world are certified to land there, navigating between 5,500-meter peaks with no radar assistance, using only visual navigation!

hero_dishes.name: Ema Datshi
hero_dishes.description: Bhutan's fiery national dish - large green chilies cooked in a rich yak or cow cheese sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Bhutanese don't use chilies as a spice, they treat them as a VEGETABLE. This dish appears at virtually every meal and is central to national identity
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every restaurant in Paro, hotel restaurants, local family homes

hero_dishes.name: Phaksha Paa
hero_dishes.description: Strips of pork cooked with dried red chilies and bok choy or radish
hero_dishes.origin_story: Pork is preserved by drying in the mountain air, then cooked with chilies - a hearty dish for cold Himalayan winters
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants in Paro town, Bukhari Restaurant

hero_dishes.name: Red Rice
hero_dishes.description: Bhutanese red rice with a nutty flavor and slightly sticky texture
hero_dishes.origin_story: Grown in the high-altitude Paro Valley, this unique rice is a staple accompaniment to every meal
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Served everywhere - it's THE rice of Bhutan

hero_dishes.name: Momos
hero_dishes.description: Tibetan-style dumplings filled with meat or cheese, steamed or fried
hero_dishes.origin_story: Brought from Tibet, momos have become a beloved snack throughout Bhutan
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors, cafÃ©s, hotel restaurants throughout Paro

signature_drinks.name: Suja (Butter Tea)
signature_drinks.description: Tea churned with yak butter and salt, high in calories for cold mountain life
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served continuously to guests as a sign of hospitality - it's impolite to let a cup go empty

signature_drinks.name: Ara
signature_drinks.description: Traditional Bhutanese rice wine or spirit, varies from mild to very potent
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Homemade in many villages, shared at celebrations and with guests

food_culture_notes: Bhutan prioritizes Gross National Happiness over GDP - reflected in unhurried meals
Every meal includes chilies - Bhutanese have an incredibly high spice tolerance
Doma (betel nut) is widely chewed and offered as hospitality
Eating with hands is traditional, though utensils are common now
